title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.9.11 | 08-04-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: So this is a very touching scene.
segments.summary: The scene is set with Bhishma on his deathbed, surrounded by the Pandavas who are filled with affection and gratitude for him.

segments.key_quote: So in a joint family system, the elders are there to guide the youngsters in every respect.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of the joint family system and the role of elders in guiding and caring for the younger generation, drawing a parallel to Bhishma's role in raising the Pandavas.

segments.key_quote: Now in the modern society, this joint family system is no longer prevalent and therefore the children are missing out a great deal of wisdom that they could have got from the elders of the family in a joint family system.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts the joint family system with modern nuclear families, highlighting the lack of elderly care and guidance for children in the latter.

segments.key_quote: So it was just plain cheating.
segments.summary: The speaker details Duryodhana's envy and cheating of the Pandavas, and Bhishma's difficult position as he was bound to support the caretaker king, Dhritarashtra.

segments.key_quote: So Dhritarashtra is equally a sinner.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Dhritarashtra is also a sinner for supporting his demoniac son Duryodhana, further emphasizing Bhishma's difficult position.

segments.key_quote: That's why Krishna arranged the battle of Kurukshetra.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by highlighting Duryodhana's negative qualities, Krishna's protection of the Pandavas, the righteousness of the Pandavas, and how Krishna arranged the battle of Kurukshetra to establish justice and allow Bhishma to die peacefully.
